title: Content Narrative Repackaging Strategy
summary:
**Conversation Overview**

The user is working on restructuring a 5-day workshop focused on building design and energy efficiency in Mosul. They provided a detailed transcript describing their proposed shift from values-based themes (using Arabic concepts like العلم for knowledge, الجمال والمنفعة for beauty and benefit) to component-based themes that follow a building construction sequence. The new structure progresses from "First Principles & Pain Points" through "Materials & Supplier Trust," "Roofs & BOQ Reality," "Walls, Windows & Wellness," and concluding with "Innovation & System Change."

The user requested Claude to review their overview and provide an updated 5-day table along with minimum and maximum slide change recommendations. Their workshop maintains a consistent "learn/apply/sell" framework across all days, emphasizing comfort, style, and cost considerations. The content includes technical elements like thermal scanning, R-values, U-values, BIM to BOQ workflows, and supplier relationship building, all contextualized for the Mosul climate and local building practices.

Claude provided a comprehensive response including a detailed 5-day overview table preserving the user's component-based approach, minimum implementation changes focusing on updating theme headers and reframing opening questions while keeping existing content, and maximum recommended changes involving visual component trackers, restructured material flow, and enhanced imagery. The response emphasized that 90% of existing content could remain unchanged, requiring primarily repackaging from a "learning values" narrative to "building better homes, component by component." Claude also suggested a phased implementation approach spanning three weeks, from minimum updates to full visual refresh with component-specific animations and storytelling elements featuring a character named Ahmed whose house serves as a case study throughout the workshop progression.

Physical arrangement: Participants break into pairs, chairs facing each other.
Materials needed: None.

Facilitator Script
“Let’s get to know each other a bit. Turn to the person next to you and finish this sentence: ‘I became an architect because …’” “Share for 3 minutes—1.5 minutes each—then we’ll call for a few volunteers to summarize what they heard.”
Key Points

“One of our past participants said, ‘I build homes because my grandmother had no indoor bathroom during winter’—a powerful reminder of why design matters.”
Activity Instructions
Step 1: Pair up and share your sentence for 3 min total (1.5 min each).
Step 2: One partner listens and remembers one key word.
Step 3: After 3 min, call out for 2–3 volunteers to share their partner’s word and why it stood out.

“Take a look at these two homes side‑by‑side. On the left, a heritage brick and stone house with a courtyard. On the right, a modern concrete‑block house.” “Let’s pause: Why do you think builders moved from designs like the one on the left to the one on the right? What factors drove that change?”

Speed & Cost: Modern methods often prioritize fast, cheap construction.
Knowledge Loss: Traditional techniques and local materials were devalued.

Solution: Redirect: “We’re exploring why we changed, not yet how each design performs.”
Issue: Discussion drifts to personal preferences.
Solution: Gently steer back: “Let’s stick to historical or economic drivers.”
Transition
“Great insights on the ‘why.’ Next, we’ll look in detail at the pros and cons of the heritage brick/stone house with courtyard.”

09:50–09:55 – Insulation Metrics 101: R & U (5 min)
Purpose: Ground everyone in the core insulation metrics so material choices make sense.
Setup: • Project the slide full-screen. • Leave space on the whiteboard for our quick formula work.
Materials needed: • Three cut-samples (foam, 3 cm cork, Isocam membrane) labeled with thickness in cm. • Excerpt of λ-value datasheet. • Whiteboard & marker.
Pre-activity checks: • Confirm each sample shows its thickness in cm. • Verify the board is clear and marker works.
Facilitator Script :: “Let’s start by defining two metrics you’ll use today: R-value tells us how well a material resists heat flow—the higher, the better. U-value is the inverse: it’s the rate of heat transfer per square meter per degree—so lower is better.
You’ll see on the slide:
R = m²·K / W  U = W / m²·K
And a quick reminder: Convert cm → m before using the formula—for example, that 3 cm cork sample is 0.03 m thick.” (Point to the “0.03 m thickness” icon.)
Key Points ::
R = thickness ÷ λ (units m²·K/W)
U = 1 ÷ R (units W/m²·K)
Always convert your thickness into meters first.
Local example :: “In Mosul, a 3 cm cork panel (λ ≈ 0.04 W/m·K) gives R ≈ 0.75 m²·K/W—compare that to 1 cm foam (λ ≈ 0.025) which is only R ≈ 0.4.”
Activity Instructions ::
Pass the three samples down each row—feel thickness and spot differences.
On the whiteboard, write R = thickness / λ using meters (e.g., 0.03 m / 0.04). Calculate R together.
Invert that R value to get U, and record it beside your formula.
Common Issues & Solutions ::
Confusing cm vs. m? → Always divide cm by 100 before plugging into R = thickness/λ.
Thinking higher U is better? → Remind: U measures leakiness—lower is more resistant.
Transition :: “Great—we can now quantify insulation performance. Next, let’s explore typical R-values in common building materials.”

11:30 – 11:40 (10 min) BATNA Description
Purpose Deepen understanding of the BATNA framework by walking through the negotiation diagram—so you know where value is created and how to find the Zone of Possible Agreement (ZOPA).
Setup
Project the Negotiate with BATNA slide.
Have a pointer or digital laser tool ready to highlight each axis and range.
Flip‑chart or whiteboard nearby to sketch simpler examples if needed.
Materials Needed
Projector and screen showing the diagram.
Whiteboard & markers (optional).
Printed handout of the diagram for quick reference (one per team).
Pre‑activity Checks
Confirm the diagram is legible from all seating areas.
Test the pointer/laser so you can highlight ranges smoothly.
Ensure each team has a copy of the slide handout.
Facilitator Script
“This is the classic BATNA negotiation diagram. On the left you see the Buyer’s Settlement Range—from their worst acceptable outcome up to their desired price. On the right is the Seller’s Settlement Range, from their worst case up to their ideal price.
The blue band in the middle is the ZOPA, or Zone of Possible Agreement—where buyer and seller ranges overlap. Any deal within that zone benefits both parties.
Your job as negotiators is to strengthen your BATNA—your alternative if this deal fails—so your worst‑case line moves closer to your ideal, narrowing the seller’s leverage. Notice how shifting even a few hundred IQD per unit can expand or contract the ZOPA significantly.”

Key Points
BATNA = leverage. A better backup plan moves your worst‑case point upward (for buyers) or downward (for sellers).
ZOPA is the sweet spot. Aim to negotiate terms inside that overlap to ensure both sides feel they’ve gained.
Range width matters. Narrower ranges make for tougher talks; broad ranges create more room to explore value‑adds beyond price.
Activity Instructions
(2 min) Walk through each labeled element on the slide: Buyer’s Worst Case → Buyer’s Desired Price → ZOPA → Seller’s Worst Case → Seller’s Desired Price.
(5 min) Split into buyer/seller pairs. Each buyer states their BATNA and desired price for a mock 250 m² retrofit; seller states theirs. Identify the ZOPA.
(3 min) Pairs share with the group: “Our ZOPA is between IQD X and IQD Y per m².”
Common Issues & Solutions
Confusion over axes? → Re‑draw a simpler line‑chart on the board showing just two points and the overlap.
BATNA unclear? → Ask, “What’s your Plan B if this buyer/seller walks away?”
No overlap (no ZOPA)? → Highlight importance of creative value‑adds or adjusting expectations to create a deal zone.
Transition
“Excellent—now that you can read and apply the BATNA diagram, let’s move on to the Negotiation Primer: BATNA & Qanaʿa, where we’ll combine these concepts with local principles of persuasion and trust.”

What influences the comfort levels of a home?
○ Thermal: How heat transfers by conduction and radiation.
○ Humidity: Moisture’s role in comfort and evaporation.
○ Airflow: Buoyancy drives stack effect.
○ Evaporation: Surface cooling via moisture phase change.
○ Mass: Thermal storage delays temperature swings.
○ Solar: Sun angle, shading, and absorption.
